advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #8</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Description of the complete Atmos system.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD. </strong></font><br><blockquote>The red part shows all the IBM-PC software boxes the VP could run.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote>TopView, one of the first serious multitasking tool for the IBM PC.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine, July 1985</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> I LEARN AT SCHOOL</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for the new model, dated april 1986. <br><br> "I learn at school, I rock at home"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I clicked"... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Close-up of the previous advert showing the various cards of the Gemini 80-BUS system.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken </b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBRAIN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Newbrain brochure only offered two models:<br><br> Model AD: with display<br> Model A: without Display <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At the fingertip of the mouse..." <br><br> "... 16/32 bits technology"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JUNE 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1986, the Alphatronic PC was bargained in many broker shops for a low price.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Never before in the history of modern computers has there been available a totally portable machine with the ability to cope with so many demands, to so many people, in so many different business areas.<br> Epson, with over 20 years experience in designing and manufacturing high quality printers, have produced the HX-20, a precision machine with its own rechargeable power supply that can be used for just about any task within to days discerning business: from data capture to word processing, from card indexing to sales order entry.<br> Communicating with other machines is no problem and the HX-20 is easily coupled to one of our fine printers. You can even link in another main computer system by using an acoustic coupler.<br> Don't be fooled by its size, the HX-20 has all the software back-up you'd expect from a much larger machine and incorporates many "bigger computer" features - 16k RAM expandable to 32k with serial interfaces, a full size typewriter keyboard, it's own built in LCD screen and a dot matrix microprinter. A micro­cassette facility is available as an optional extra.<br> A complete computer that will either stand on its own or could be the obvious extension to your existing system.<br> More and more people are finding out just how big the small compact HX-20 is. Why don't you find out for yourself - you­ owe it to your business.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The incredible Secam color micro-computer !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-503 is a YIS-303 with more memory (32 kb) and a proper keyboard.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #7</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JANUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A computer for all french people"</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: 3.5'' disk-drive (2.88 Mb), Hard-disk from 105 Mb to 1.5 Gb
computer.colors: NeXTstation: 4 (black, white and two shades of grey)ColorStation: 4096 colors
computer.coprocessor: FPU Motorola 68882 (math co-processor)Motorola 56001 Digital Signal Processor
computer.description:
The NeXTstation was a light version of the NeXTcube.
The magnetic-optical drive has been replaced by a hard-disk, as NeXTcube users found this drive too slow compared to "modern" hard-disks available then.
The thin design of the case didn't make it possible to keep the NeXTbus slots.
There were several models, including a NeXTstation (25 Mhz), a ColorStation with color display (4096 colors, 25 Mhz) and a ColorStation Turbo (33 Mhz).
Thanks to Computers Forever for his help.
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, 85 keys, 2 buttons opto-mechanical mouse
computer.media: 3.5'' disk-drive (2.88 Mb), Hard-disk from 105 Mb to 1.5 Gb
computer.name: NeXT Station
computer.ports: SCSI internal connector, SCSI2 external port, DSP, video output, proprietary port for NeXT laser printer, 2 x RS232 connectors, Ethernet
computer.ram: 8 Mb (12 Mb for Colorstations) up to 32 Mb

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> RIGHT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Note the 3.5" floppy drive slot on the right hand side of the case.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Five keys, above the arrows keypad, allow sound and brightness adjustments as well as system power On/Off.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>MegaPixel display connectors, from left to right:<br> • Headphone jack<br> • Left & right sound output jacks<br> • Main unit connector, carries the power as well as video, sound, keyboard and mouse data<br> • Keyboard mini-DIN socket<br> • Microphone jack <br><br> Main unit connectors:<br> • SCSI-2 connector<br> • Dual RS-423 serial ports<br> • Digital Signal Processor port<br> • MegaPixel display connector<br> • NexT laser printer port<br> • Thin and twisted-pair Ethernet 10 MB ports </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OPENED</strong></font><br><blockquote>At left side, switching power supply unit and fan,<br> at right side: 105 MB HDD and 3.5" 2.88 MB FDD.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>More info needed about the function of each chip.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEXT LASER PRINTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>300/400 dpi (software-selectable) 8 pages per minute. Uses a dedicated high-speed serial interface.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SET OF MANUALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Along with a sheet of NexT stickers!</blockquote>

computer.sound: DSP Motorola 56001 @ 25 Mhz (16 bits, 44.1 Khz, stereo, 24k RAM upgradable to 576 kb)Speaker built-in the monitor
